Dear Mr. Fernandez:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on February
22, 2021. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, and MISEP requirements, a
written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing
rules are also violations of MISEP. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the
date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or MISEP citation.
 Repeat violations require an explanation on why the corrective action plan
was not successful.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 552-3662.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12325 License recommendation.
(2) An agency shall document foster home license changes in
the foster home record and shall communicate the changes
immediately to the department in the manner prescribed by
the department.
One of eight foster home files reviewed contained documentation indicating that
the agency failed to immediately communicate changes to the foster home license
to the department, as required. A renewal inspection report which indicated that
the foster parents separated in June causing the foster mother to move to a new
home; however, a new application (3889) and licensing transaction record (3706)
indicating the address change and the removal of the foster father from the license
was not submitted until the following January. Additionally, no relocation study was
completed on the foster mother’s new residence.
R 400.12325 License recommendation.
(3) Except for an original license, an agency shall recommend
to the department the issuance of a regular license or the
continuation of an active license only when all rules are in
compliance or both of the following conditions exist:
(b) A written corrective action plan has been
developed. The plan shall be in compliance with all of
the following requirements:
(i) Specify the methods, the persons
responsible, the time frames for correction;
methods for ensuring the safety of any children
placed in the home; how continuing compliance
will be maintained once compliance is achieved;
consequences if the corrective action plan is not
completed; and what documentation will be
required to demonstrate compliance or
completion.
4

One of eight foster home files reviewed contained a corrective action plan that did
not ensure the safety of the children in the home. The corrective action plan was
required after it was determined that the foster parent cussed at and slapped a
youth. The corrective action plan merely required the family to review and resign
the agency discipline policy, failing to address the cause of the foster parent’s
action or prevent future incidents.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all
of the following documents:
(c) A copy of the initial evaluation with written endorsement
by the borrowing agency that the evaluation is acceptable.
(d) A copy of the current reevaluation with written
endorsement by the borrowing agency that the evaluation
is acceptable.
(e) A list of all children currently placed in the home.
(f) Documentation that the foster parent has received
orientation to the policies of the borrowing agency.
(g) A copy of the foster parent /agency agreement signed
by the foster parent and the borrowing agency.
(h) A copy of the current children's foster home license
application and children's foster home licensing transaction
record documents from the certifying agency.
One of three borrowed bed foster home files reviewed lacked documentation
obtained prior to placement for subsection (c) through (h) as required.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the
child's record before a change of placement occurs:
(a) Reason for the change in placement.
(b) If the child is not returned to the parent then the
reason why return is not possible.
(c) If the child is not reunited with siblings or placed
with a relative, then the reason why those placements
are not possible.
(d) Consideration of the factors identified in R
400.12404(4).
(e) Replacement preparation, regardless of the child’s
age, appropriate to the child’s capacity to understand,
which includes an explanation to all relevant parties as
to why the change is necessary.
(f) Notification to the parents, referral source, lawyer
guardian ad litem, and courts when applicable, of the
change in placement.
5

(g) Information about the child was shared with the new
placement, consistent with the requirements of R
400.12417.
(h) The child’s new location and address.
(i) That the current foster parent was notified in writing
of the following information:
(i) Not less than 14 calendar days in advance, of
the change, except when prior notification would
jeopardize the child’s care or safety. If prior
notice is not provided, then the agency shall
notify the foster parent, at the time of the
change, why prior notice was not given.
(ii) Of the current foster parent’s rights
concerning the change in placement.
Six of eight open foster care files reviewed where a youth changed placement
lacked the information required in subsection (a) through (h) which would have
been captured in an action summary (DHS-69).
2020 Renewal Inspection Report; Corrective Action Plan Approved 3/6/20.
Two of eight open foster care files reviewed where a youth changed placement
lacked notification in writing to the foster parent as required
2020 Renewal Inspection Report; Corrective Action Plan Approved 3/6/20.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless a greater frequency is medically indicated:
(i) For a child under 2 years of age, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 3 months
before being placed in foster care or a new physical
examination shall be completed within 30 calendar days after
being placed in foster care.
(ii) For a child 2 years of age or older, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 12 months
before placement or a new physical examination shall be
completed within 30 calendar days after placement.
(iii) A physical examination every 14 months.
Two of eleven case files reviewed lacked a required medical examination as
required. One file the examination was not completed within the first 30 days of
entering care and the other file the annual examination was not completed within
14 months.
6

R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(f) The provision of a dental examination and any treatment
required for each child who is 4 years of age and older,
including both of the following:
(ii) A dental reexamination shall be obtained at least
every 18 months, unless a greater frequency is indicated.
One of eleven case files reviewed lacked a dental examination as required.
R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement of
a child:
(a) Child’s name.
(b) Child’s date of birth.
(c) Available known information about the child’s
health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors
relating to the care of the child.
(f) All known behavioral problems of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or
replacement of the child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster
parent to provide a stable, safe, and healthy
environment for the foster child and the foster family,
including information about siblings who do not reside
in the foster home.
(i) Name of assigned social service worker.
One or eight open foster care files reviewed lacked the initial placement outline
(DHS-3307) covering the required information in subsections (a) through (i).
2020 Renewal Inspection Report; Corrective Action Plan Approved 3/6/20.
7

R 400.12502 Program statement.
(2) An agency shall give a copy of the program statement to a
youth before placement in independent living.
One of one independent living files reviewed where the youth entered independent
living during the period under review, lacked documentation the agency provided a
program statement to the youth prior to placement in independent living.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2020 Renewal Inspection Report; Corrective Action Plan Approved 3/6/20.
2019 Interim Inspection Report; Corrective Action Plan Approved 3/5/19.
R 400.12503 Policy and procedures.
(3) An agency shall provide a youth in independent living with
a copy of the agency's policies and procedures required by
this rule.
One of one independent living files reviewed where the youth entered independent
living during the period under review, lacked documentation the agency provided
policies and procedures to the youth prior to placement in independent living.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2020 Renewal Inspection Report; Corrective Action Plan Approved 3/6/20.
2019 Interim Inspection Report; Corrective Action Plan Approved 3/5/19.
R 400.12504 Eligibility requirements.
(2) All of the following shall be in the case record before a
youth is placed in independent living:
(a) How the youth meets the eligibility requirements for
the specific program the youth is being placed into.
(b) The basis for concluding that a youth exhibits self-
care potential.
(c) That the youth’s social service worker has
personally observed and determined that the living
situation is safe and that the youth has a bed and has
access to cooking and bathing facilities.
(d) The availability of specific and relevant resources
that may provide for suitable social, physical,
educational, vocational, and emotional needs of a
youth.
(e) An evaluation of a youth's need for supervision and
a plan for providing the level of supervision determined
necessary.
(f) Proof that financial support to meet the youth’s
housing, clothing, food, and miscellaneous expenses is
available.
8

One of one independent living files reviewed where the youth entered independent
living during the period under review, lacked documentation for the rationale for
selection of independent living for the youth as the most appropriate placement.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2020 Renewal Inspection Report; Corrective Action Plan Approved 3/6/20.
2019 Interim Inspection Report; Corrective Action Plan Approved 3/5/19.
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(1) There shall be a mutually agreed upon contract between
the youth and the agency specifying all of the following:
(a) The responsibilities of the agency and the youth.
(b) A plan for education or work.
(c) An agreement for the youth to meet with the worker
at least one time per calendar month.
(d) The location where the youth is living.
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth and
the social service worker. The contract shall be reviewed and
updated at least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
Three of three independent living files reviewed lacked documentation of an
independent living contract with the youth as required. In one case there were no
independent living contracts. In the other two cases there were not independent
living contracts every 90 days as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2020 Renewal Inspection Report; Corrective Action Plan Approved 3/6/20.
2019 Interim Inspection Report; Corrective Action Plan Approved 3/5/19.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The
facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements except for the
following:
ISEP 6.19 Assessments and Service Plans, Content
(c) Service plans shall be signed by the caseworker, the
caseworker’s supervisor, the parent(s), and the child(ren), if of
age to participate. If the parent(s) or child(ren) or both are not
available or decline to sign the plan, the service plan shall
include an explanation of the steps taken to involve them and
shall identify any follow-up actions to be taken to secure their
participation in services.
9

Eight of eleven open files reviewed lacked the required signatures on the case
service plans.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—Previous Citation ISEP 6.33
2020 Renewal Inspection Report; Corrective Action Plan Approved 3/6/20.
2019 Interim Inspection Report; Corrective Action Plan Approved 3/5/19.
ISEP 6.24 Visits, Between Siblings
(a) DHHS shall ensure that children in foster care who have
siblings in custody with whom they are not placed shall have
at least monthly visits with their siblings who are placed
elsewhere in DHHS foster care custody.
One of four open foster care files reviewed where siblings were not placed together,
the monthly sibling visits were not occurring each month as required.
2020 Renewal Inspection Report; Corrective Action Plan Approved 3/6/20.
ISEP 6.22 Visits, Worker-Parent
(2) for each subsequent month, at least one face-to-face contact
with each parent and phone contact as needed, with at least on
contact in each three-month period occurring in the parent’s
place of residence.
Three of seven open foster care case files with the goal of reunification reviewed
lacked documentation of the required worker-parent contact each month.
2020 Renewal Inspection Report; Corrective Action Plan Approved 3/6/20.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS policy violation. Please note that
there are additional DHS Policy requirements that may not be included in section
1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Policy requirements except
for the following:
FOM 722-8C Parent Agency Treatment Plan & Service Agreement
Signatures
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate,
including those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care worker,
supervisor, foster parent, caregiver, any youth age 14 and
older and in the case of placement agency foster care cases,
the local DHS office designee.
10

Four of seven open foster care files reviewed lacked the foster parent signature
on the parent agency treatment plan in a timely manner.
2020 Renewal Inspection Report; Corrective Action Plan Approved 3/6/20.
FOM 722-06H Caseworker Contacts
The primary caseworker must have face-to-face contact with
each child as indicated below.
First Two Months after Initial Placement or a Placement
Change
The caseworker must have at least two face-to-face contacts
per month with each child in the first two months following an
initial placement or a placement change.
The caseworker must have at least one face-to-face contact
per month with each child in subsequent months.
Five of eleven open case files reviewed lacked documentation of two visits each
month in the first two months of placement as required.
One of eleven open case files reviewed lacked documentation of at least one
face-to-face in subsequent months.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2020 Renewal Inspection Report; Corrective Action Plan Approved 3/6/20.
2019 Interim Inspection Report; Corrective Action Plan Approved 3/5/19.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings
Types and Timeframes
FTMs must occur within the required time frames.
Two of eleven files reviewed lacked documentation that a Case Plan
Development/Reassessment Family Team Meeting was completed as required.
Three of eleven foster care files reviewed lacked the required DHS 1105 Activity
Report uploaded into MiSACWIS as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2020 Renewal Inspection Report; Corrective Action Plan Approved 3/6/20.
2019 Interim Inspection Report; Corrective Action Plan Approved 3/5/19.
11

FOM 801 Health Services for Children in Foster Care
Medical Passport requirements.
Four of eleven open case files reviewed lacked the medical passport being
completed as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—Previous Citation ISEP 6.49
2020 Renewal Inspection Report; Corrective Action Plan Approved 3/6/20.
2019 Interim Inspection Report; Corrective Action Plan Approved 3/5/19.
FOM 722-8E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary
The DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary is
used to document specific administrative actions or changes
in a case, including:
 Child fatality.
 Change in caseworker or organization.
 Change in parent contact information.
 Foster care transfer to adoption.
 Change in placement.
 Temporary break from placement.
 Program or case closing.
Four of seven closed case files reviewed lacked a case closing action summary
as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—Previous Citation FOM 722-9C
2020 Renewal Inspection Report; Corrective Action Plan Approved 3/6/20.
2019 Interim Inspection Report; Corrective Action Plan Approved 3/5/19.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 Clarification of independent living rule requirement was provided when a youth
has a legal status of Young Adult Voluntary Foster Care. For any youth placed in
an independent living placement, regardless of their legal status, the
Independent Living Section of the Child Placing Agency rules apply.
 Reminder to complete Casey Life Skill assessment per policy requirements.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
 The agency was not in need of consultation.
12

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period in response to the Renewal Inspection
Report. The agency had citations for application request, reevaluation, special
investigation, case service plan supervisory approval, relative home study and
relative search which were not found in violation during this audit. The remaining
items the agency was cited for during the Renewal Inspection were repeat violations
during this audit.
Several foster care, licensing and supervisory staff were interviewed. All noted the
challenges and changes due to the pandemic within the past year. However, each
staff reported being extremely supported and amazing communication throughout
the entire year by both by direct supervisors and upper management. Staff also
acknowledged activities to support retention of employees and foster homes. CHRI
storage and destruction were observed via Facetime due to COVID.
VII. DCWL FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or policy. Upon receipt
of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue
on a regular license.
